summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami Division to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies and Applications Office, requesting scanning, automation, and data formatting assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the employer of Alfredo Rodriguez and the central figure in a child prostitution case. An address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain information about his additional underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims and attempted to sell it rather than provide it to authorities, obstructing the investigation into Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division of the FBI opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: FBI requests processing of Epstein-related phone records
events.description: The FBI Miami Division submitted a formal request to the Document Conversion Laboratory and Special Technologies Office to scan, automate, and format telephone records obtained from an address book in the Rodriguez/Epstein case.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (FBI DocLab address: 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.
The FBI was processing telephone records from the address book, with a specific target number 340-771-6264, for incorporation into its Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.
The document is an internal FBI workflow request, showing the procedural steps taken to digitize and analyze evidence in the Epstein-related investigation.
